div.head: Kīla
Indrakīla
div.p: Is it me who is missing something here, or is there some misunderstanding in the way some translators translate the Sanskrit śaṅku or kīla synonyms — nail or spike — as “dagger”? Is it possible that these translators do so based on the association of the Tibetan translation of the Sanskrit word — phur pa / phur ba / phur bu — with the ritual object of the same name used in Tibetan rites that indeed has an elaborate form of a dagger?

While it can’t be ruled out with certainty that kīlas or śaṅkus took a form of ritual daggers also in the Indian context when used for ritual purposes I would be grateful if somebody could point me to any textual or archaeological evidence for this, it seems a bit out of place to call them “daggers” in non-ritual contexts, for example when they are used to oppress beings in hell where the ground is studded with spikes / nails, and the same fall from the sky. Also in contexts when some villagers arm themselves with “rods, spikes, and canes,” it is unlikely that these spikes śaṅku are daggers.
Translating śaṅku / kīla as “dagger” in the description of hells in the early sūtras could be planting Tibetan content in texts where it doesn’t historically belong.

I also recently saw the word triśaṅku translated as “triple dagger.” The term, synonymous, with triśūla, most likely means a three-forked spike or trident, so common in India. I find it difficult to visualize it as a dagger.
